awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Developing a Parallel and Distributed Computing Concepts Curriculum Enhancement for the Computer Science Principles Course
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is initiating design of a Parallel and Distributed Computing (PDC) curriculum enhancement for the Computer Science Principles (CS0) course that is also applicable to the corresponding high school advanced placement (AP) course.   
Modern computing systems routinely employ high levels of parallelism (e.g., multiple cores, graphics processors) and distributed computing (e.g., cloud services).  PDC significantly affects daily lives, and its importance in solving meaningful societal problems can inspire students to take a deeper interest in applying computing in STEM fields and beyond. However, most CS0 curricula are founded predominantly on older, sequential models of computing. CS0 has multiple purposes that address many audiences, and is now seen as a vehicle for increasing interest among students, especially from underrepresented groups, for studying computing in depth or to major in computer science. It has thus been the subject of an effort to create a new AP exam, with associated high school courses. Since the AP exam is still in a pilot phase, there is a brief window for amending the curriculum to reflect 21st century computing. The potentially vast impact of the AP course could quickly settle into educating students under the old sequential paradigm, acquiring an inertia that makes it difficult to change. This collaborative effort is developing PDC curriculum guidelines for CS0 and AP courses through gathering expert input and involving necessary stakeholders to ensure that an appropriate curriculum is developed and adopted. The goal is for students to gain an understanding of how modern computing technology actually functions, rather than being taught an obsolete operational model. 
The effort is following a process similar to the proposers' highly successful prior effort to design a PDC guideline for undergraduate curricula, which was incorporated into the ACM standard curriculum. The approach begins with a thorough survey of the state of practice in covering PDC topics in CS0. The survey is followed by a workshop attended by experts and stakeholders to draw upon their knowledge and experience. Then a select steering committee is formed that advises the investigators on the design of a curriculum and helps them identify means to bring it to fruition. The effort seeks the broadest possible dissemination of the results to have the greatest possible impact.
Broad impact is the core of this effort, which seeks to expand awareness and appreciation of the important concepts at the foundation of PDC, to students in many different disciplines and in high school. Making these interesting and exciting topics more accessible to a wider range of students should generate deeper interest in the study of computer science and the application of concurrent computation in science, engineering, and commerce. Advancing PDC education further enables advances in science and engineering, which depend ever more on high performance computing, by providing the next generation of practitioners and researchers with the necessary skills and knowledge to routinely recognize how and where PDC concepts may be applied.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to begin the process of developing a proposal for additional coverage of parallel and distributed computing (PDC) concepts in the Advanced Placement Computer Science Principles (CSP) course. PDC is an important 21st century computing topic that was omitted from the initial design of the CSP curriculum. Nearly all computation since the early 2000's involves the use of parallelism, and much of our modern networked infrastructure depends on distributed computing. PDC relies on additional concepts beyond those used in traditional, sequential, computation. It is thus critical for modern students to be introduced to those concepts as they first learn about computational thinking, so that their problem solving approaches are not limited to 20th century computational paradigms.

We organized a series of meetings with a diverse set of stakeholders, including CSP course designers, high school CS education organizations, college level educators including those from institutions serving underrepresented groups, industry, and government, to identify the most appropriate PDC concepts for inclusion in a revision of the CSP curriculum. Because CSP is meant to be a key component of the CS For All initiative, the choice of concepts had to be limited to those which could be taught in a wide range of high school contexts. 

Our initial meeting, in May of 2016, brought together a diverse set of stakeholders, including CSP course designers, high school computer science education programs, college level instructors including those from institutions serving underrepresented groups, industry, and government. The meeting was organized using a World Cafe model in which participants worked in small groups to discuss a question related to the goals of the project. A member of each group was tasked with encouraging everyone to write their ideas on a sheet of paper in the middle of the table. After a given time, the groups would disperse and reform randomly so that the ideas could propagate through the entire meeting. After three rounds, the participants were asked to identify common themes from their discussions, which were written on a white board and recorded. Then a new or follow-up question would be given and the process would repeat. In addition to the summaries, forty-two pages of notes were gathered. These were transcribed by a graduate student who then looked for additional themes, and organized the notes into a report that was circulated to the participants for comment. 

A second meeting was held in November of 2016, in which a smaller group of stakeholders met with one of the CSP course designers who was also a member of the College Board AP group that was exploring revision of the CSP curriculum. That meeting further refined the concepts that could potentially be proposed as part of the revision. Work continued through weekly discussion meetings among the PIs for the project, and with the PI visiting the CSP course designer in June of 2017 for further discussions. An opportunity then arose, unexpectedly, to submit a proposal for updating the curriculum in August of 2017. We quickly responded with a submission.

It should be noted that we originally proposed that our effort would lead to preparations for beginning the process of shepherding the inclusion of PDC concepts into a future CSP revision because we had been informed that the next revision would not happen for several years, and that it would be a lengthy process. We are thus pleased to report that we have been told that the next version of the CSP course will include PDC concepts that we proposed. Our effort has thus succeeded far beyond what we had anticipated would be possible. 

The impact of this result is that high school students across the United States will now be introduced to computational thinking in a manner that includes PDC concepts. They will thus be better prepared for careers that make use of 21st century computational paradigms, and the country will gain a workforce that is more capable of making the best use of modern computational resources.
